The CC coupling of CO plays a crucial role in the reduction of CO/CO2 to C2+ compounds. Controlling the activity and active sites of the catalyst proves to be an effective method to achieve controllable CC coupling. By doping metals into fullerene to form endohedral metallofullerenes (EMF), a strategy emerges to achieve unique catalytic activity. Herein, we report that embedded nickel-metallofullerenes (Nin@C60) as an efficient catalyst can achieve controllable CC coupling of CO, thereby promoting the generation of C2 products. The results show that it is thermodynamically feasible for Nin clusters to embed into C60 to form Nin@C60, electronic structure analysis reveals that Nin clusters can activate C60 through electron transfer. Subsequently, research finds that the physically adsorbed CO on C60 and Nin@C60 surface can directly form O*C*CO intermediate through controllable CC coupling, with an extremely low activation energy barrier (0.10 ∼ 0.41 eV). Among them, Ni6@C60 has the lowest activation energy barrier, which is 0.10 eV. This work provides new theoretical insights into CC controllable coupling and the design of novel catalysts for efficient CO/CO2 conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Embedded nickel-metallofullerenes Controllable C–C coupling CO Reaction mechanism DFT Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The selective conversion of C1 molecules into high value-added C2+ compound is a very attractive but very challenging research topic [1–4]. CO is an important part of C1 molecules, CO conversion has attracted widespread attention in industry to form a series of alkanes and alcohols [5–7]. But directly converting syngas into the C2 product remains a formidable challenge [8–11]. Both theoretical and experimental studies have identified CO dimerization as a key step in the synthesis of C2 products from CO [12–14]. In recent years, the CC coupling mechanism of CO on the surface of various catalysts has attracted wide attention from researchers [15–20]. Koper et al. [15,21,22] found that CO can dimerize on Cu(100) surface to form *O*CCO which is co-adsorbed by CO's C and O atoms. At the same time, *O*CCO is a key intermediate for the production of ethanol and ethane on the Cu(100) surface. Liu et al. [16] found that the synergy of Cu0 and Cu+ active surface in MEOM catalyst (Cu metal embedded in oxidized matrix) can promote CO dimerization to O*C*CO. Du et al.'s [17] research revealed that atomically dispersed asymmetric Cu–B pair in the Cu-B@g-C3N4 catalyst is beneficial to the dimerization of CO to O*C*CO. Our previous research [23,24] found that on the metal-supported graphene surface, CO generates stable chemically adsorbed O*C*CO through the O*CCO intermediate. Although the surface of these catalysts can effectively form CO dimerization, CO dimerization on the surface of these catalysts has a higher activation energy barrier. Therefore, it is very necessary to find a catalyst that can lower the activation energy barrier of CO dimerization. Due to tunable molecular structures, spatial confinement and surface effects, low dimensional carbon materials have been widely used and developed as non-noble metal catalysts or even non-metallic catalysts, such as two-dimensional graphene, one-dimensional carbon nanotubes, and zero-dimensional fullerene [25]. As an important component of the carbon family, fullerenes have also attracted widespread attention as a catalyst [26,27]. As with other common low-dimensional carbon materials, the lack of active sites on the fullerene cages prevents fullerenes from being used directly as catalysts. But does not preclude their use for this function, as some fullerene derivatives can be used as catalysts [28]. Derivatives of C60, such as doped C60, have been the focus of research in recent years [29]. Depending on the location of dopant, C60 can be functionalized into three categories: substitution doping [30], exohedral doping [31], and endohedral doping [32,33]. Among them, embedded doping is similar to metal-supported graphene [24] and embedded metal nanowires carbon nanotubes [25], this approach to catalyst design preserves the intact carbon surface. At the same time, inert carbon materials can be activated through charge transfer between metals and carbon materials, and due to the regularity of the carbon material itself, the generated active sites are single and have good catalytic selectivity. Therefore, endohedral metallofullerenes (EMFs) formed by doping metals within fullerene have attracted significant attention due to fundamental scientific curiosity and practical considerations. EMFs and its applications have been widely investigated both theoretically and experimentally [34–37]. Du et al. [34] found that when a metal atom is embedded in C60 (M@C60), M@C60 has excellent HER activity, even better than Pt and MoS2 catalysts. Sc3N@C68 [36], Sc6@C80 and Sc10@C100 [38] also exhibit excellent stability and HER activity, and the Gibbs free energy of adsorbed hydrogen is close to 0. EMFs is not only an effective catalyst for HER, but also has very good activity for ORR. Lai et al. [35] found that transition metals (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni Cu) embedded in C60 have better ORR activity. Chen et al. [39] found that Fe cluster-based EMFs (M4@MN4C60) has ORR performance comparable to Pt. At the same time, electronic structure calculations show that the encapsulated Fe4 cluster causes electrons to gather around the Fe atoms in the active center, thereby weakening the *OH binding and Enhance ORR performance. Although the catalytic performance of EMFs has been widely studied, there has been no research on EMFs as catalysts for the selective conversion of C1 molecules. In this work, the mechanism of Nin@C60 as a catalyst for controllable CC coupling of CO was systematically studied. First, we explored the possibility of Nin (n = 1 − 6) clusters embedded inside C60, followed by an examination of CO adsorption by Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) and the potential for CO to generate OCCO through CC coupling. Binding energy and formation energy calculations show that Nin can be easily embedded inside C60, with this process being thermodynamically feasible. Nin improves the catalytic activity of C60, facilitating the facile coupling of CO to generate OCCO on the surface of Nin@C60. 2 Calculation methods All spin polarized DFT calculations were performed with the Vienna Ab initio simulation package (VASP) [40–42]. The exchange correlation function was handled using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) formulated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [43,44]. Long-range dispersion corrections were considered within the DFT-D2 method [45]. The dispersion coefficient C6 and vdW radius R0 for H, C, O, Ni used in our DFT-D2 method were taken from previous works. The scale factor S6 was set to 0.75 because the GGA-PBE function was employed [46,47]. The plane-wave basis set energy cutoff was set to 400 eV, and the Brillouin zone integrations were done using a 1 × 1 × 1 k-point mesh. The electronic self-consistency criterion was set to 10–4 eV and a force convergence tolerance of 0.02 eV/Å. A 15.625 nm3 supercell was constructed to avoid the interaction with their own images. To investigate the minimum energy path, the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was employed to find approximate transition states (TS), and a quasi-Newton algorithm was used to optimize the likely TS until the force acting on the atom was <0.02 eV/Å, and finally the nature of TS was verified by only one imaginary frequency existing in vibrational normal mode. The energy barrier (ΔEa) of each reaction step is expressed by the energy difference between the TS and the initial state (IS). Solvation effects were considered by using the implicit solvation model implemented in VASPsol [48,49]. The formation energy ΔEform of Nin (n = 2 − 6) clusters is defined as Δ E form = E total − n E atom n There, E total is the total energy of Nin (n = 2 − 6) clusters, E atom is the energy of the Ni atom, n is the atom numbers of Nin (n = 2 − 6) clusters. The formation energy ΔEform of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) is defined as Δ E f o r m = E total − ( 60 × E C atom + n × E Ni atom ) 60 + n There, E total is the total energy of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6), E C atom is the energy of the C atom, E Ni atom is the energy of the Ni atom, n is the atom numbers of Ni atom. The binding energy ΔEbind between the Ni clusters and C60 is defined as Δ E bind = E total − E Ni clusters − E C 60 There, E total is the total energy of Nin@C60, E Ni clusters is the energy of Nin, E C 60 is the energy of C60. The adsorption energy ΔEads between the adsorbate and the substrate is defined as Δ E ads = E total − E substrate − E adsorbate There, E total is the total energy of the adsorbate/substrate system, E substrate is the energy of the substrate, E adsorbate is the energy of the adsorbate. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 The structures and electronic properties of Nin@C60 The optimized geometric structures of Nin (n = 2 − 6) clusters is shown in Fig. S1. Nin (n = 1 − 6) inside Fullerene cage to form endohedral metallofullerenes (Nin@C60) was further explored. The optimized geometric structures of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) are displayed in Fig. 1 , and the formation energy (ΔEform), the binding energy (ΔEbind) and the distance between the Ni atoms (dNi-Ni) of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) are displayed in Table 1 . All structures of Nin@C60 are shown in Figs. S2–S6, and detailed descriptions of the structures are described in the supporting information. The structure of the Nin clusters (n = 2 − 6) calculated in this article is consistent with previous research [35]. Subsequently, when Nin (n = 2 − 6) is embedded inside C60, the chemical bond is formed between Nin and C60, and there is a strong interaction between Nin and C60, which is similar to the structure of Aun@C60 [29,37]. Interestingly, many studies have shown that in single atom metal embedded fullerenes, the metal atom is located at the center of C60 [34,37]. However, the calculation results in this work show that Ni1 and C60 have lower energy to form chemical bonds, similar to Th@C82 and Ca/Na/Sr@C60, [50,51] as shown in Fig. S2. Therefore, subsequent research will choose the optimal structure of Ni1@C60 calculated in this work. According to the calculation results, the changes in the bond length of Nin in Nin@C60 (n = 2 − 6) are compared. For n = 2 − 4, compared with the free state, the bond lengths of Nin are all elongated, which shows that Nin can be easily embedded inside the C60. This embedding also involves stretching the distances between Ni atoms to stabilize C60. For n = 5 and 6, the bond length of Nin is shortened, due to increased steric hindrance from a greater number of Ni atoms, complicating their embedding inside C60. This is similar to previous research [37]. However, the changes in Nin bond length is within a reasonable range, indicating that embedding is still feasible for n = 5 and 6. As shown in Table 1, the changes in formation energy and adsorption energy for Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) is compared. We found that for even numbers of n, the formation energy increases with n, while for odd numbers, it first decreases then increases. Despite this, the formation energy of Nin@C60 is consistently higher than C60. However, the adsorption energy and formation energy are both negative, indicating that Nin embedding into C60 is thermodynamically feasible. The Bader charge and the charge density difference (CDD) of Nin@C60 are further studied. As shown in Fig. 2 , CDD shows that when Nin is embedded in C60, Ni transfers the charge to the C60 surface, and Ni and C60 form a Ni-C covalent bond. When Ni1 is embedded in C60, as shown in Fig. 2a, electrons are gathered between Ni and the five-membered ring of C60 that forms chemical bond with Ni, Ni atom have obvious electron loss, and the valence of Ni is +0.76. The five-membered ring carbon atoms of C60 that forms chemical bond with Ni has −0.43 electrons as a whole, which indicates that the five-membered ring at this time not only obtains electrons from Ni atom, but also transfers electrons to other carbon atoms in C60. Therefore, as show in Fig. 2a, it can be observed that there is red electron cloud around the five-membered ring. When Ni2 and Ni3 are embedded in C60, the valence states of Ni atoms bonded to C60 are +0.45 and +0.42 respectively, while the valence states of Ni atoms not bonded to C60 are +0.04 and +0.20 respectively. At the same time, CDD can be seen that Ni atoms that are not bonded to C60 transfer charges to other Ni atoms, and there is no obvious charge transfer with C60, as shown in Fig. 2b and c. Fig. 2d shows that the valence state of the Ni atom in Ni4, which is bonded to the C60 six-membered ring is +0.43, while the valence state of the Ni atom that is bonded to the five-membered ring is +0.30. This is mainly due to the charge transfer between Ni atoms bonded to the six-membered ring and more C atoms. Interestingly, when Ni5 is embedded in C60, the valence state of Ni atoms bonded to the five-membered ring is +0.41, while the valence states of the Ni atoms bonded to the six-membered ring are +0.44 and +0.38 respectively, as shown in Fig. 2e. This is due to the different bond lengths of Ni and C atoms. The bond length between the Ni atom with valence state of +0.44 and the C atom is 2.12 Å, while the bond length between the Ni atom with valence state of +0.38 and the C atom is 2.18 Å, which indicates that the activation ability of these two Ni atoms towards the surrounding C60 is different. Fig. 2f shows that the valence state of each Ni atom of Ni6 is +0.43, there is charge transfer between the entire C60 and Ni6, and electrons gather on the surface of C60. This shows that when more metal atoms are embedded, C60 is activated more evenly. Electronic property analysis shows that there is a strong charge transfer between C60 and Nin. C60 receives electrons from Nin clusters, resulting in C60 electron redistribution, which enable C60 to have good catalytic performance. 3.2 C2O2 adsorption on Nin@C60 surface In our previous study, [23,24] CO can dimerize on the surface of Ni/Cu-supported graphene to form chemically adsorbed C2O2, while C2O2 can be further hydrogenated to form C2 products. Therefore, in this work we will further explore the adsorption of C2O2 on the Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surface. First, we studied the adsorption of a CO molecule on the C60 and Nin@C60 surfaces, and the results are shown in Fig. S7. Same as the adsorption of a CO molecule on Ni/Cu-supported graphene surface before, [23,24] a CO molecule is physically adsorbed on the C60 and Nin@C60 surfaces. The adsorption energy of CO adsorbed on the surface of C60 and Nin@C60 is about −0.12 eV. This indicates that neither C60 nor Nin@C60 can directly activate CO. Similar to Ni/Cu-supported graphene, when two CO molecules are co-adsorbed on the C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surfaces, CO can dimerize into chemically adsorbed O*C*CO. When C2O2 adsorbs on the surface of C60 and Nin@C60, there are three possible adsorption sites (ortho-C, meta-C and para-C). As shown in Fig. 3 and S7, OCCO adsorbs on C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 5) surfaces, there are only two adsorption configurations: ortho-C and para-C, while in Ni6@C60 surface, there are three adsorption configurations. The adsorption energy and Bader charge of the most stable adsorption configuration of C2O2 adsorbed on the C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surfaces are shown in Table 2 . Unlike the most stable adsorption of C2O2 on Ni/Cu-supported graphene surface at the meta-C site, OCCO is adsorbed on the ortho-C between the two six-membered rings on the surface of C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) through two C atoms, as shown in Fig. 3. The structural diagram and description of other configurations of OCCO on C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surfaces are shown in Fig. S7 and supporting information. More interestingly, the C atom of C60 that forms a chemical bond with OCCO does not directly form a chemical bond with the Ni cluster. This is similar to the adsorption of OCCO on the surface of Ni/Cu-supported graphene. When OCCO bonds with C atoms that directly bond with Ni/Cu, the adsorption configuration of OCCO is unstable. As shown in Fig. 3, when O*C*CO is chemically adsorbed on the surface of C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6), the distance between C of OCCO and C of C60 is 1.58∼1.59 Å, and the distance between C and O in OCCO is 1.20∼1.21 Å. Compared with free C60 surface, when O*C*CO is adsorbed on Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surface, the CC bond length in O*C*CO decreases, and the adsorption energy of O*C*CO increases. When O*C*CO is adsorbed on the Ni6@C60 surface, the adsorption energy is the strongest, which is −1.28 eV. Bader charge analysis found that when O*C*CO is adsorbed on the surface of free C60, OCCO has a charge of +0.002, but O*C*CO is adsorbed on the surface of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6), O*C*CO is all negatively charged, and when O*C*CO is adsorbed on Ni2@C60, O*C*CO has the largest negative charge, which is −0.24. The correlation of the adsorption energy of OCCO on the C60 and Nin@C60 surfaces is consistent with the correlation of the formation energy of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6). When n is even number, as n increases, O*C*CO adsorption energy increases. When n is odd number, as n increases, O*C*CO adsorption energy first increases and then decreases. Compared with free graphene, CO on the surface of graphene cannot be dimerized into chemically adsorbed C2O2, but CO dimerization can occur on the surface of free C60. This indicates that the dimerization of CO on the surface of C60 is not only the electronic contribution of Nin clusters to C60, but the curvature of C60 also affects the dimerization of CO. The curvature of C60 itself causes C60 to have a certain activity. 3.3 Mechanism of CO dimerization on Nin@C60 surface OCCO is a key intermediate for the formation of C2 species from syngas. It is very important to study the mechanism of coupling of two CO molecules to generate OCCO. Therefore, we continued to study the mechanism of CC coupling of CO to chemisorbed O*C*CO on the surface of C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6). The potential energy surface of two physical adsorption of CO molecules to form O*C*CO is shown in Fig. 4 . The structure diagrams of two physical adsorption CO molecules, transition state (TS) and O*C*CO are shown in Fig. S8. Unlike CO dimerization on the Ni/Cu-supported graphene surface, there is no metastable single-C adsorption O*CCO during the CO dimerization process on C60 and Nin@C60 surfaces. Two physically adsorbed CO molecules are directly coupled through TS to form O*C*CO. The detailed description of the reaction process is provided in the supporting information. The evolutions of charge density difference (CDD) and projected density of states (PDOS) in the direct CC coupling of CO to O*C*CO via TS has been further studied. Taking the evolution process of Ni6@C60 surface as an example, as shown in Fig. 5 . When two CO molecules are physically adsorbed on the surface of Ni6@C60, there is no charge transfer between CO and C60, as shown in Fig. 5b When entering TS, there is charge transfer between CO and C60, and a small amount of electron clouds gather between CO and C60. C60 transfers electrons to CO, as shown in Fig. 5d When chemically adsorbed OCCO is formed, there is a clear electron cloud between OCCO and C60, and C60 transfers electrons to OCCO, causing OCCO to stably adsorb on the surface of C60, as shown in Fig. 5f. During this process, the number of electrons in CO changed from 0 to −0.08e, and the final number of electrons in O*C*CO was −0.13e. PDOS can also confirm the enhanced interaction between CO and catalyst during CC coupling process. As shown in Fig. 5a, the peak of CO remains in a gaseous state, indicating that CO has not been activated by C60. In TS, there is a significant overlap between CO and C60 at −6 and −7 eV, indicating a weak interaction between CO and C60, as shown in Fig. 5c. In Fig. 5e, when chemically adsorbed O*C*CO is generated, the overlapping peaks between CO and C60 increase, indicating a strong interaction between CO and C60. Interestingly, the orbitals of Ni6 clusters remain largely unchanged during the catalytic process, and there is a strong interaction between them and C60, further confirming the stability and source of activity of the catalyst. The above results reveal the electronic structural changes of CO generating O*C*CO on the surface of Ni6C60, further confirming that CO can directly CC couple to generate O*C*CO on the surface of Nin@C60. When CO dimerizes on C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surface, the correlation between activation energy barrier and reaction energy, and the correlation between activation energy barrier and OCCO adsorption energy are further studied. As shown in Fig. 6 a, when CO is dimerized, the activation energy barrier of the reaction has a strong linear relationship with the reaction energy, and R2 is 0.97. This indicates that the more energy released by the reaction, the lower the activation energy required for the reaction. As shown in Fig. 6b, the correlation between activation energy barrier and OCCO adsorption energy is not as good as the correlation between activation energy barrier and reaction energy, but R2 is 0.89, which indicates that there is also a better linear relationship between activation energy barrier and OCCO adsorption energy. On Nin@C60 surface, when the adsorption energy of OCCO is stronger, the activation energy to form OCCO may be lower. By comparing the linear relationship between the activation energy barrier, reaction energy, and adsorption energy, it can be considered that on the surface of endohedral metallofullerenes (Mn@C60) catalyst, the greater the adsorption energy of OCCO, the more energy is released by the reaction, CO dimerization may require lower activation energy. If the subsequent hydrogenation of O*C*CO is an electrocatalytic process, the solvation effect and competition of HER need to be considered. The implicit solvation model of the direct CC coupling mechanism of CO has been calculated here, as shown in Figure S11. When considering solvation, compared with C60, the activation energy barrier of CO on the surface of Nin@C60 is reduced, which is different from the vacuum state. On the surface of C60, Ni1@C60 and Ni6@C60, the activation energy barrier slightly increases when considering solvation. On other surfaces, the activation energy remains basically unchanged, consistent with the vacuum state. Similar to the vacuum state, when considering solvation, the activation energy of CO is the smallest on the surface of Ni6@C60, at 0.19 eV. The effects of solvation on the correlation between reaction energy, OCCO adsorption energy and activation energy were further studied, and the results are shown in Fig. S12. When considering the solvation effect, like the vacuum state, there is a strong linear relationship between the reaction energy, the adsorption energy of OCCO and the activation energy barrier. The results indicate that the solvation effect has a certain impact on the direct CC coupling of CO, but the change in activation energy is not significant and the effect is relatively small. The subsequent discussion and analysis will still be based on the results of the vacuum state. HER is a competitive reaction of CO electrocatalytic reduction, so under the influence of solvation effect, the HER mechanism on the surfaces of C60 and Nin@C60 have been further studied. As shown in Fig. S13a, the study finds that on the surface of Nin@C60, the value of ΔGH* is relatively small (−0.13∼0.44 eV), which shows that Nin@C60 is a better HER catalyst. There is a great competition for CORR. However, further research on adsorption energy reveals that the adsorption energy of H* on Nin@C60 surface is much lower than that of O*C*CO, therefore O*C*CO preferentially adsorbs on the catalyst surface, as shown in Fig. S13. The results indicate that OCCO electrocatalytic reduction has strong competitiveness. Compared with Ni/Cu-supported graphene catalysts, the dimerization activation energy barrier of CO on C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) surfaces is much lower than Ni/Cu-supported graphene (0.85 and 0.94 eV). Even the activation energy barrier for CO dimerization on the Ni6@C60 surface is only 0.10 eV, which can even be ignored. This is mainly because CO on Ni/Cu-supported graphene surface needs to form O*C*CO through a metastable single atom C chemisorbed O*CCO intermediate, while CO directly CC couples on Nin@C60 surface to generate O*C*CO. On the surface of Ni/Cu-supported graphene, although the formation of O*C*CO from two CO molecules is an exothermic process, it is thermodynamically supported. However, the formation of metastable O*CCO from two CO molecules is an endothermic process, resulting in a high activation energy barrier for the entire process. And CO directly couples with CC on the surface of Nin@C60 to form O*C*CO, which is a one-step reaction and a strongly exothermic process, resulting in a low activation energy barrier for CO to form O*C*CO on the surface of Nin@C60. This shows that C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6) have better catalytic activity for CO dimerization. Therefore, we believe that Nin@C60 are excellent catalysts for the CC controlled coupling of CO, and we have reason to believe that the hydrogenation of C2O2 into C2 products has good selectivity and activity. 4 Conclusion In this work, the structure of Nin (n = 1 − 6) clusters embedded inside C60 to form Nin@C60 and the mechanism of direct CC coupling of CO on Nin@C60 surface were systematically studied. First, our analysis of the binding energies and formation energies of Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6), along with changes in bond lengths after embedding Nin (n = 1 − 6) in C60, confirmed the thermodynamically feasibility of forming Nin@C60. Meanwhile, electronic structure analysis revealed that Nin can transfer electrons to C60, altering its electronic structure and activating its catalytic activity. Finally, the controlled CC coupling of CO on the Nin@C60 surface was studied. It was found that physically adsorbed CO generates O*C*CO intermediate through CC coupling on the surface of C60 and Nin@C60 (n = 1 − 6), with an exceptionally low activation energy barrier ranging from 0.10 to 0.41 eV. Among them, the surface activation energy barrier of Ni6@C60 is the lowest at 0.10 eV. It was confirmed that Nin@C60 can be used as a catalyst for controlled CC coupling of CO. This work provides new insights into the design of endohedral metallofullerenes and their use as catalysts for the conversion of C1 molecules into C2 products. coredata.dc:description: The CC coupling of CO plays a crucial role in the reduction of CO/CO2 to C2+ compounds. Controlling the activity and active sites of the catalyst proves to be an effective method to achieve controllable CC coupling. By doping metals into fullerene to form endohedral metallofullerenes (EMF), a strategy emerges to achieve unique catalytic activity. Herein, we report that embedded nickel-metallofullerenes (Nin@C60) as an efficient catalyst can achieve controllable CC coupling of CO, thereby promoting the generation of C2 products. The results show that it is thermodynamically feasible for Nin clusters to embed into C60 to form Nin@C60, electronic structure analysis reveals that Nin clusters can activate C60 through electron transfer. Subsequently, research finds that the physically adsorbed CO on C60 and Nin@C60 surface can directly form O*C*CO intermediate through controllable CC coupling, with an extremely low activation energy barrier (0.10 ∼ 0.41 eV). Among them, Ni6@C60 has the lowest activation energy barrier, which is 0.10 eV. This work provides new theoretical insights into CC controllable coupling and the design of novel catalysts for efficient CO/CO2 conversion.
